rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Camassa is my favorite professor! He presents the material to make it interesting, & class is usually very entertaining. Exams are pretty fair.

This professor is terrible. He's difficult to understand as well as extremely unorganized. The class didn't follow the syllabus at all. He is rude and constantly interrupts his students to correct them on objective and irrelevant details. If you have a class with him, get out while you still can. He is the worst professor I've ever had.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Miller is a wonderful professor! She really cares about students and is very helpful if you go to her office hours.  She ends class early for homework questions and gives concise answers to questions. Tests are easy - definitely do the practice tests, and she allows a 1-page formula sheet. I definitely recommend her class.
Dr. Miller is an awesome prof!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took calc in high school, and still had to study a lot for this class. However, if you do study thoroughly for each test, it's possible to do well. Definitely go to class. Also, he curves your grades at the end of the semester, so don't completely freak out. I thought I would end up with a B or B-, but ended up getting an A-.

I had very little exposure to calc before taking this course, but had considered myself good at math, and I struggled quite a bit. He would barely touch the surface of a topic in lecture, and then the homework would feel impossible. He assigns quite a bit of homework. Tests were pretty tricky, just because partial credit was rare.

Dr. Jones explained the concepts well and I found his pace to be appropriate. He's a fairly funny guy too. (Not funny in the normal sense, but like professor funny). Take notes, pay attention, don't make dumb mistakes on the exams, and you should be good.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Very difficult class, need to put in lots of work. Textbook (Bretscher) was useless so you'll probably need to refer to other textssources. His lectures weren't helpfulengaging, I basically self-studied this class. Gives large amounts of HW especially during weeks of tests. First test was easy but the second test and final were much, much harder.

I'm only a freshman, but by far the hardest class I've ever taken. I thought I was good at math, then I took this class. By the end of the semester it mostly makes sense, but during it I was never more lost.

This is one of the best teachers I have had, going out of his way to help you individually if he knows you're trying hard. He is NOT the right teacher for everyone. Be prepared to exhaust the material before class, in order to benefit from his brilliance. He can teach very fast, but will slow down and explain things clearly if you ask him to.

I have had Professor Kumar before for Math 233. There is no doubt, his tests are very stressful. However, he spends a great amount of time making sure students know each section very well and is always helpful when students have questions. He asks questions in class, so if students don't understand, he will notice and help correct this.

Very nice professor.  His accent is difficult to understand at first, but you'll get the hang of it.  The quiz questions come directly from the homework, but the tests are what killed my grade in this class.  He throws a bunch of curve balls at you.  This ended up being my lowest grade at UNC.

He was a very nice man, but he was not clear at all. His tests were extremely difficult. There was no room for mistakes. Unless you are a math whiz, I would not suggest taking him, because you will recieve insufficient help.
No Comments
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: One of the very best professors in the math department (I'm a math major, trust me!). Very clear, good lecturing style. His tests are hard, but he grades fairly.
took honors section which was hard, though a good class when one can keep up with the material, often goes to fast and not easy to follow,

Rimanyi is a pretty good teacher, compared to some others at the math department.  He is extremely helpful and is willing to schedule additional office hours if necessary.  The book is very useful in this class and doing extra problems always helps.  As stated already, he does sometimes put questions from the book on the exam.
Very good teacher, fair grading, lectures are very clear.

Decent math teacher, if a stodgy one.  Test scores were low, but curve is generous.  If you totally butcher a test and do well later he's willing to diminish or drop the first exam.  Many of his exam problems were also in the textbook.. if that helps :-).

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Mitran definitely knows the material very well.  He expects you to be more than proficient with understanding and be very active in reading ahead.  Be ready to program a lot. I worked extremely hard to finish the hw, but those are the majority of your grade.  He can be blunt and condescending and but not necessarily unwarranted.  Text is useful

Prof. Mitran is a very interesting professor, but his lectures are long and sometimes don't cover what you need to know on the homework assignments. Tests are difficult and he doesn't really review for them at all.

Lectures are long, but you have to pay attention or else you will fall behind. Each homework takes about 8 hours so start much earlier. He uses half-functioning virtual machine called Tarheel Linux that you might have to ask ITS to help you install. He uses Octave too. The tests are easy but you have to know the concepts and steps.
Soooo many homework ,  long lecture, better learn those material by yourself
Best professor I have ever had in the math department. He holds high expectations for his students, but his tests are very fair and he is also a fair grader.

Dr. Mitran is undoubtedly a very intelligent individual. However, he fails to clearly communicate many of the ideas he wishes to teach in class, and I learned more reading outside papers on the topics discussed than I did from his lectures or notes. He is also an incredible tough grader and can be very derisive towards questions he feels are inane.

The course is demanding, and he has no interest in holding your hand. He often belittled those who asked questions in class, creating an environment where everyone was afraid to speak up.  Not a nice guy.  That said, he lectures well.  I learned a lot in this class, but I wasn't a rewarding experience.

Mitran's MATH 566 was the most difficult mathematics class of my undergraduate career (BS Math).  Having survived the class though, I can honestly say I learned more from it than from any other.  Mitran is a strict and intimidating professor, but I feel this is a fair trade for the amount of knowledge he tends to impart.
Prof. Mitran will push you and make things difficult, but he's fair and you get a ton out of the class. Highly recommended!!!11!
Lectures were interesting and well motivated. By far the best lecturer I have had. The workload is hard but fair and helpful to learning the material.
Honestly this is by far the worst professor I have ever had
No Comments
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Pretty fun class, Mucha's lectures were very well organized and he taught intelligently but not pedantically. He was very available for office hours and help if needed. Good sense of humor and ability to keep the class light while never completely going off on tangents. I would recommend the class; the subject matter is difficult but Mucha is good.

Very enthusiastic and helpful. The class (MATH233) was rather difficult but Mucha was very willing to help on an individual level despite 50+ in the class. Lectures focus more on solving problems rather than deriving equations. I enjoyed this but it might work less for some.

PLEASE I repeat PLEASE do not take this class. I took this class on the premise that it would be told based on biological principles instead of     the usual physics based calculus. He did this for about a week then he just started teaching some foreign language. Half of the class was lost and his lectures are very unorganized. On a positive if you

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Honestly,  I love this man. He saved me in calculus. Whenever I needed help, he was there. His lectures are long and tend to put you to sleep, but if you can stay awake through them, you'll understand how thorough and well put together they are.

Sawon is brilliant and helpful, very clear but class moves quickly so pay attention. also, do the effing homework - annoying but worth it! class is longest ever but passable without always attending lecture. overall good professor - and an aussie! ;D

Sawon was not a difficult teacher, easy B if you pay attention in class and easy A if you have taken calculus before. (You will still need to pay attention in class). Attendance is basically optional, so it is harder to pay attention in class than it sounds.

Sawon is clear throughout lectures and always asks if anyone has questions. He does a great job at explaining concepts and taking his time. Homework is online, which is really annoying, but it is doable. The tests get progressively harder but are also doable. Dont really need the textbook, just the webassign code.

Quiet, mild-mannered, math-magician. Intelligent, but a really nice guy if you get to know him well enough. Go to class, and try to stay awake. If you have trouble with web-assign, speak up in a recitation. Sawon loves to help, often with a quiet joke a soft smirk. A mystery, worth getting to know better.

You don't have to show up to class which is nice. 2 tests are fair, one sucks for the midterms. Trust me, you don't need to understand the Web Assigns. Just do them by whatever means necessary and don't take them lightly. This curve needs to be huge though, I'm anxiously waiting to see how nice it is.

Very clear in his examples, willing to answer questions, and discuss any problems during office hours. He assigns homework based on the material covered during class, and every now and then will throw a curveball. He uses webassign, which isn't the most user-friendly website, but the problems are relevant to the test. He has an Australian accent.
Sawon is very clear in his examples, and will answer any questions.  Also, he is very helpful in office hours.  He also has a British accent.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great teacher, really nice, and cares a lot about her students. I had her for MATH 119 and she taught very in depth, and even showed us how to use excel. Easy to get an A if you study a couple hours for each exam. We also did a lot of group work. Homework was rarely collected, but was sometimes used in class for group work (again, a lot of it).
loved her... super helpful and a good person

This class was the easiest thing ever, i guess because i had taken calc 2. The homework and assignments were tedious, required a lot of effort but were barely worth anything. As a person who already knew the material, i think that she her explanations were kinda confusing and took the long route in solving problems. Barely used the text book .
Probably one of the easiest classes I've taken at UNC.  If you don't have to take an upper level math, definitely take this class. She also teaches you how to use Excel, which is a bonus.

You will probably learn more practical information taking this class with her than with anyone else.  The drawback is you will put in twice the amount of effort into this course and probably get a lower grade than you would taking this course with anyone else.

This was a difficult course for me because I hadn't had a math course in 2 years.  She explained things pretty well and actually seems to care about her students.  The course was rushed because it was during a summer session, but she managed to get all the material in.
